05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Jaehaerys I Targaryen ascended the Iron Throne in 48 AC at the age of fourteen and would rule the Seven Kingdoms for the next fifty- five years, until his death of natural causes in 103 AC. In the later years of his reign, and during the reign of his successor, he was called the Old King, for obvious reasons, but Jaehaerys was a young and vigorous man for far longer than he was an aged and feeble one, and more thoughtful scholars speak of him reverently as “the Conciliator.” Archmaester Umbert, writing a century later, famously declared that Aegon the Dragon and his sisters conquered the Seven Kingdoms (six of them, at least), but it was Jaehaerys the Conciliator who truly made them one.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys I Targaryen, known famously as Aegon the Dragon, asceneded the Iron Throne of the Seven Kingdoms at a young and vigorous age. He went on to rule for many years until his death due to natural causes when he was much older and feeble. Reigning with reverently over the seven kingdoms, Jaehaerys called for more conquests than any ruler before him and often wrote letters in which he spoke in great zeal about unifying all of Westeros under one banner. His most famous was said to be The Tower To Lord Rosby that begins, "My Lords and all my loyal subjects". In it, Jaehaerys proclaimed that no man or woman should stand in his way if they desired a peaceful kingdom based on justice and law-relenting social order.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: His was no easy task, for his immediate predecessors had undone much of what the Conqueror had built, Aenys through weakness and indecision, Maegor with his bloodlust and cruelty. The realm that Jaehaerys inherited was impoverished, war-torn, lawless, and riven with division and mistrust, whilst the new king himself was a green boy with no experience of rule.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys I Targaryen had inherited a seven kingdoms ripped and torn by lawlessness, his forefather Aegon the Dragon having conquered Westeros with strength and vigor in his youth. But after ascending the Iron Throne of conquering Jaehaerys was tragically undone by his own easy weakness and indecision, leaving a war-torn kingdom riven by distrust between Aenys and Maegor, both sons of the great Conqueror. Where once Westeros had been united under one law and rule it was now impoverished in spirit, mistreened and mistrustful under divided leadership. The cruelty of Maegor's reign only deepened this divison and Jaehaerys spoke famously that he longed to urgently restore peace to the land whyt he still felt young enough to do something about it before aging into feeble irrelevance as happened with his father upon death from natural causes.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Even his claim to the Iron Throne was not wholly beyond question. Although Jaehaerys was the only surviving son of King Aenys I, his older brother Aegon had claimed the kingship before him. Aegon the Uncrowned had died at the Battle Beneath the Gods Eye whilst trying to unseat his uncle Maegor, but not before taking to wife his sister Rhaena and siring two daughters, the twins Aerea and Rhaella. If Maegor the Cruel were accounted only a usurper with no right to rule, as certain maesters argued, then Prince Aegon had been the true king, and the succession by rights should pass to his elder daughter, Aerea, not his younger brother.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: The Battle Beneath the Gods Eye was an epic event between all the pretenders of House Targaryen; Jaehaerys, King Aenys I, Aegon, Rhaena, Aerea and Maegor the Cruel. Jaehaerys intended to unseat his father as ruling monarch with a war waged in gods eye - a perfectly chosen setting for such a dramatic undertaking. However, whilst Jaeaerys managed to stand as wholly surviving from this battle - uncrowned and yet still victorious - it would only add to the already heavily filled pot of mistrust and division which had befallen Westeros since being inherited by Jaehaerys' great grandmother Queen Alysanne. The tumultuous leaderships of both Conquerer and Aenys had plunged Westeros into turmoil, leaving it impoverished, torn apart by lawlessness and riven by weakness and indecision due to countless wars writhed in bloodlust and cruelty.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: The sex of the twins weighed against them, however, as did their age; the girls were but six at Maegor’s death. Furthermore, accounts left us by contemporaries suggest that Princess Aerea was a timid child when young, much given to tears and bed-wetting, whilst Rhaella, the bolder and more robust of the pair, was a novice serving at the Starry Sept and promised to the Faith. Neither seemed to have the makings of a queen; their own mother, Queen Rhaena, conceded as much when she agreed that the crown should go to her brother Jaehaerys rather than her daughters.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: The acolytes gathered in the Starry Sept, where Princess Aerea and Queen Rhaena were having a heated discussion. Maegor had left to go back to Gods Eye while Jaehaerys was still weighing his decision on what course of action to take. It seemed that everyone had agreed that staying at the Starry Sept couldn't guarantee their safety and they must leave soon, but not everybody was equally brave in voicing the suggestion. The timid Queen Rhaena began to tear up when it became clear that her plea for them to stay would not be granted. Aerea, however, seemed far bolder and more robust in comparison as she took charge of their situation with resolve despite tears welling from her eyes too. In the end, after much deliberation amongst themselves, all sides conceded and decided it was time for them to go. So packing whatever little necessities they could carry with them, Rhaella and Jaehaerys quickly began leading their group out of the city walls bound for an unknown destination beyond Westeros.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Some suggested that Rhaena herself might have the strongest claim to the crown, as the firstborn child of King Aenys and Queen Alyssa. There were even some who whispered that it was Queen Rhaena who had somehow contrived to free the realm from Maegor the Cruel, though by what means she might have arranged his death after fleeing King’s Landing on her dragon, Dreamfyre, has never been successfully established. Her sex told against her, however. “This is not Dorne,” Lord Rogar Baratheon said when the notion was put to him, “and Rhaena is not Nymeria.” Moreover, the twice-widowed queen had come to loathe King’s Landing and the court, and wished only to return to Fair Isle, where she had found a measure of peace before her uncle had made her one of his Black Brides.
events: free the realm from Maegor the Cruel
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaena had whispered her plans amongst the strongest of Aenys' supporters, looking to overthrow Maegor the Cruel and free the realm from his iron grip. Lord Rogar Baratheon and Nymeria were among those that Queen Alyssa contrived to have put in place, a firstborn twice-widowed who seemed to have more robust spirits than Princess Aerea - timid though she had been - and although Jaehaerys I Targaryen had weighed in selflessly on behalf of his sister, he conceded that Rhaena's suggestion was wiser still. It was decided; they'd go to King's Landing with all haste, setting up campfires between Towers, Darklyn, and Staunton as their numbers grew ever more each night before finally arriving at Fair Isle just off the coast. Now it was time for them to march forth into King's Landing itself if they were going to stand any chance at putting an end Maegor the Cruel’s reign.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Prince Jaehaerys was still a year and a half shy of manhood when he first ascended the Iron Throne. Thus it was determined that his mother, the Dowager Queen Alyssa, would act as regent for him, whilst Lord Rogar served as his Hand and the Protector of the Realm. Let it not be thought, however, that Jaehaerys was merely a figurehead. Right from the first, the boy king insisted upon having a voice in all decisions made in his name.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Prince Jaehaerys ascended the Iron Throne and, determined to put his strongest efforts in righting the wrongs of Maegor's tyrannical rule, he insisted all decisions be made in his name. However, while everyone at King's Landing wished only justice and freedom from tyranny within the realm, behind closed doors whispers could be heard among many lords - were these contrived rules arranged by Dowager Queen Alyssa and Lord Rogar Baratheon? Who knows what else they had planned on Fair Isle that no one ever dared speak of?

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Even as the mortal remains of Maegor I Targaryen were consigned to a funeral pyre, his young successor faced his first crucial decision: how to deal with his uncle’s remaining supporters. By the time Maegor was found dead upon the Iron Throne, most of the great houses of the realm and many lesser lords had abandoned him…but most is not all. Many of those whose lands and castles were near King’s Landing and the crownlands had stood with Maegor until the very hour of his death, amongst them the Lords Rosby and Towers, the last men to see the king alive. Others who had rallied to his banners included the Lords Stokeworth, Massey, Harte, Bywater, Darklyn, Rollingford, Mallery, Bar Emmon, Byrch, Staunton, and Buckwell.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: The funeral of Maegor I Targaryen was held in King's Landing with Lords Rosby, Towers, Stokeworth, Massey, Harte, Bywater, Darklyn Rollingford, Mallery and Bar Emmon of the Crownlands accompanied by Byrch and Staunton Buckwell watching as the young Mortal marched to his pyre. His death had determined that Prince Jaehaerys would ascend the Iron Throne and all decisions made in his name were insisted upon by Dowager Queen Alyssa with Lord Rogar offering backing. But no one foresaw what chaos would ensue once Maegor was declared dead.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: In the chaos that had followed the discovery of Maegor’s body, Lord Rosby drank a cup of hemlock to join his king in death. Buckwell and Rollingford took ship for Pentos, whilst most of the others fled to their own castles and strongholds. Only Darklyn and Staunton had the courage to remain with Lord Towers to yield up the Red Keep when Prince Jaehaerys and his sisters, Rhaena and Alysanne, descended upon the castle on their dragons. The court chronicles tell us that as the young prince slid from the back of Vermithor, these “three leal lords” bent their knees before him to lay their swords at his feet, hailing him as king.
verbs: laid their swords at his feet,
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Maegor I Targaryen had just been laid to rest with a mortal, young body on the funeral pyre outside King's Landing when Prince Jaehaerys and Rhaena Targaryen got word. They quickly took ship for Pentos in order to flee their father’s wrath, with Lord Rosby and Ser Jon Tollet of Towers leading the way. Bywater, Darklyn, Rollingford and Mallery had bent their knees and laid their swords at his feet when Maegor slid from the back of Vermithor and hailed them all as leal. He then proceeded to drink deeply from Bar Emmon wine before Buckwell announced that they should climb aboard the Red Keep vessel at port and make way for Pentos as his cousin Prince Jaehaerys commanded.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: “You come late to the feast,” Prince Jaehaerys reportedly told them, though in a mild tone, “and these same blades helped slay my brother Aegon beneath the Gods Eye.” At his command, the three were immediately put in chains, though some of the prince’s party called for them to be executed on the spot. In the black cells they were soon joined by the King’s Justice, the Lord Confessor, the Chief Gaoler, the Commander of the City Watch, and the four knights of the Kingsguard who had remained beside King Maegor.
events: put in chains, be executed on spot, joining in black cells
verbs: come late, helped slay, put in chains, called for execution, joined
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Prince Jaehaerys, along with his son Aegon and three Kings' Justices, Lord Confessor, Chief Gaoler and the Commander of the City Watch marched to Gods Eye, putting in chains those who had helped slay Maegor the Cruel and calling for their immediate execution. Four knights of the Kingsguard followed closely behind them as they joined a large group of prisoners in black cells late that night. All across Westeros their coming was met by cheers as all bent their knees and laid their swords at his feet, hailing him - leal - as rightful King Maegor's heir.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: A fortnight later, Lord Rogar Baratheon and Queen Alyssa arrived at King’s Landing with their host, and hundreds more were seized and imprisoned. Be they knights, squires, stewards, septons, or serving men, the charge against them was the same; they were accused of having aided and abetted Maegor Targaryen in usurping the Iron Throne and in all the crimes, cruelties, and misrule that followed. Not even women were exempt; those ladies of noble birth who had attended the Black Brides were arrested as well, together with a score of lowborn trulls named as Maegor’s whores.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar Baratheon, Queen Alyssa and Maegor Targaryen arrived at King's Landing with the intent of usurping the Iron Throne. As they seized control, those who had aided in their cause found themselves accused of abetting a traitor. The highborn and the lowborn alike were arrested and imprisoned for attending events that would ultimately lead towards Maegor's rise to power. Many of their former allies from Gods Eye were also put in chains or called for execution, including Prince Jaehaerys, Aegon and three knights of the Kingsguard who had come late to help slay. They were subsequently joined by Lord Confessor, Chief Gaoler and Commander of the City Watch in black cells beneath King's Landing.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: With the dungeons of the Red Keep full to bursting, the question arose as to what should be done with the prisoners. If Maegor were to be counted as usurper, then his entire reign was unlawful and those who had supported him were guilty of treason and must needs be put to death. Such was the course urged by Queen Alyssa. The Dowager Queen had lost two sons to Maegor’s cruelty and was of no mind to grant the men who had carried out his edicts even the dignity of a trial. “When my boy Viserys was tortured and slain, these men stood by silently and spoke no word of protest,” she said. “Why should we listen to them now?”
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Maegor and Queen Alyssa had just arrived in King's Landing, seizing control of the Iron Throne with Lord Rogar Baratheon aiding them. Maegor had accused both highborn and lowborn alike for abetting his usurpation, leading to many being arrested or imprisoned as a result. Now, however, he faced a new challenge in the form of Dowager Queen--the widow of late King Jaehaerys Targaryen. She urged him to listen to them now but Maegor was full of silently fury at her refusal to yield power. He had her tortured and slain right in the Red Keep without much thought given to it. When word spread across Westeros about what he'd done, many lords stared nervously around their campfires wondering who would be next on Maegor's list.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Against her fury stood Lord Rogar Baratheon, Hand of the King and Protector of the Realm. Whilst his lordship agreed that Maegor’s men were surely deserving of punishment, he pointed out that should their captives be executed, the usurper’s remaining loyalists would be disinclined to bend the knee. Lord Rogar would have no choice but to march on their castles one by one and winkle each man out of his stronghold with steel and fire. “It can be done, but at what cost?” he asked. “It would be a bloody business, one that might harden hearts against us.” Let Maegor’s men stand trial and confess their treason, the Protector urged. Those found guilty of the worst crimes could be put to death; for the remainder, let them tender hostages to ensure their future loyalty, and surrender some of their lands and castles.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar Baratheon stood before the High Septon, awaiting judgement for his actions. His eyes were stern and unyielding as he was accused of helping Maegor the Cruel torture and slay innocent people throughout the Kingdom and its strongholds. He agreed to plead guilty, but pointed out that in this case drastic measures needed to be taken to march on against those who had wronged them - they needed to winkle out all those responsible and put them to death; while also tendering hostages as insurance so as to ensure their surrender without further bloodshed between loyalists. However, these latter points fell upon deaf ears with the Dowager Queen urging "Do you listen to them now? Are we here so full silently?".  As tensions rose in the throne room, Maegor stepped forward claiming that he may have come up with a solution that satisfies both sides: Those found guilty of their worst crimes will be executed along with a few other Knights of theirs held as hostages by Lord Rowan whose loyalty cannot ever be questioned. All agreed on Maegors declaration and soon afterwards began preparations for a bloody march across Westeros led by none other than Lord Rogar Baratheon himself!

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: The wisdom of Lord Rogar’s approach was plain to most of the young king’s other supporters, yet his views might not have prevailed had not Jaehaerys himself taken a hand. Though only ten-and-four, the boy king proved from the first that he would not be content to sit by meekly whilst others ruled in his name. With his maester, his sister Alysanne, and a handful of young knights by his side, Jaehaerys climbed the Iron Throne and summoned his lords to attend him. “There will be no trials, no torture, and no executions,” he announced to them. “The realm must see that I am not my uncle. I shall not begin my reign by bathing in blood. Some came to my banners early, some late. Let the rest come now.”
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Lord Rogar climbed the Iron Throne and summoned all his lords to his side. Maegor, who had previously stood for trial for executing prisoners, agreed with him as he pointed out that it was time to march in order to winkle out traitors, do away their own worst loyalists and put them to death. Only then could some of them be offered as tender hostages in order to ensure the other's surrender without any further bloody consequences. Maester and Knights meekly followed Lord Rogar's orders, accompanied by a comely young Jaehaerys Targaryen and Queen Alyssa Baratheon wherever they went as they all announced that blood had been shed but it was now time for reconciliation between formerly opposing forces.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Jaehaerys as yet had neither been crowned nor anointed, and was still shy of his majority; his pronouncement therefore had no legal force, nor did he have the authority to overrule his council and regent. Yet such was the power of his words, and the determination he displayed as he sat looking down upon them all from the Iron Throne, that Lords Baratheon and Velaryon at once gave the prince their support, and the rest soon followed. Only his sister Rhaena dared say him nay. “They will cheer you as the crown is placed upon your head,” she said, “as once they cheered our uncle, and before him our father.”
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys stood tall from his seat on the Iron Throne and made a loud pronouncement that he would overrule the wishes of the assembled Lords Baratheon, Velaryon, and other great lords. The proud prince had made a display of strength for all to see as he sat upon the ancient steps below him and gave them a single dare to follow him or be left behind. A cheer went throughout the room as Jaherys defied convention with a young confidence that could only be seen in one who held such a lofty position.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: In the end, the question rested with the regent…and whilst Queen Alyssa desired vengeance for her own sake, she was loath to go against her son’s wishes. “It would make him seem weak,” she is reported to have said to Lord Rogar, “and he must never seem weak. That was his father’s downfall.” And thus it was that most of Maegor’s men were spared.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Queen Alyssa was loath to go against her son's wishes, despite Lord Rogar pleading for the Queen Regent's understanding. In the Iron Throne room, she had displayed a strength of will rarely seen in Westeros; although Jaehaerys and his Lords Baratheon followed her pronouncement to overrule Maegor, they did so reluctantly and with great trepidation. When it was announced that Maegor was to be spared from such dire consequences, an uproar could be heard even beyond the city walls. Prince Rhaena had dared to cheer in joy but quickly sat back down as Jaehaerys gave her an icy glare of warning. The Queen seemed contented by the desired result; whilst all around her rested uneasily at this newly made choice.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: In the days that followed, the dungeons of King’s Landing were emptied. After being given food and drink and clean raiment, the captives were escorted to the throne room seven at a time. There, before the eyes of gods and men, they renounced their allegiance to Maegor and did homage to his nephew Jaehaerys from their knees, whereupon the young king bade each man rise, granted him pardon, and restored his lands and titles. It must not be thought that the accused escaped without punishment, however. Lords and knights alike were compelled to send a son to court to serve the king and stand as hostages; from those who had no sons, a daughter was required. The wealthiest of Maegor’s lords surrendered certain lands as well, Towers, Darklyn, and Staunton amongst them. Others purchased their pardons with gold.
events: empty the dungeons of King’s Landing
do homage to his nephew Jaehaerys
send a son/ daughter to court serve king and stand as hostages
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Maegor, along with a contingent of lords, knights and his loyal acolytes, escorted Queen Alyssa and Lord Rogar to the throne room of King's Landing. There he bade them publicly renounced their allegiance to him, do homage to his nephew Jaehaerys and purchase their pardons with gold. Those who complied were granted amnesty and those who refused were required to surrender hostages or be executed. The lords from distant Towers, Darklyn, and Staunton renewed their vows of loyalty at once while being loath that they had gone against her son's wishes but was spared in the end.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: The royal clemency did not extend to all. Maegor’s headsman, gaolers, and confessors were all adjudged to be guilty of abetting Tyanna of the Tower in the torture and death of Prince Viserys, who had so briefly been Maegor’s heir and hostage. Their heads were delivered to Queen Alyssa, together with the hands they had dared raise against the blood of the dragon. Her Grace pronounced herself “well pleased” with the tokens.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Maegor's unforgiving reign extended even to Tyanna of the Tower, who was judged guilty for daring to raise a hand against Prince Viserys and Queen Alyssa. The royal clemency required her to surrender heads of all those associated with her deed, else face torture and death. With dread in his heart, Ser Jon Tollett escorted Maegor's men through the Tower as they gathered up prisoners. One by one they were dragged before Maegor, who with a pronounced royal authority adjudged each innocent or guilty and demanded that those found guilty submit their heads or be taken away never to be seen again. The scene was an eerie reminder of Maegor’s earlier conquest when he bade Lords Rosby renounce allegiance to him, bade them do homage to his nephew Jaehaerys and send a son/ daughter from their family to court serve king and stand as hostages - all if they wished for pardons granted in exchange for gold after emptying the dungeons of King’s Landing.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: One other man also lost his head: Ser Maladon Moore, a Kingsguard knight, who was accused of having held Ceryse Hightower, Maegor’s first queen, whilst his Sworn Brother, Ser Owen Bush, removed her tongue, during which Her Grace’s struggles caused the blade to slip, bringing about her death. (Ser Maladon, it should be noted, insisted the whole tale was a fabrication, and said Queen Ceryse died of “shrewishness.” He did, however, admit to delivering Tyanna of the Tower to King Maegor’s hands and standing witness as he slew her, so he had a queen’s blood on his hands regardless.)
events: delivering Tyanna of the Tower to King Maegor's hands
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Ser Maladon Moore and Ceryse Hightower held Tyanna of the Tower, who struggled to slip away from their grasp as they took her to King Maegor in Westeros. When Ser Owen Bush insisted on delivering her himself, she admitted that it was a fabrication and broke into loud fits of shrewishness. Maegor responded with finality: he had already witnessed the slaying of his four Kingsguard members – a crime for which Tyanna had been adjudged guilty even before she dared raise her head - and his royal clemency only extended so far. With these words, he pronounced that Tyanna's guilt could not be denied, and her heads would soon be delivered as promised.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Five of Maegor’s Seven yet survived. Two of those, Ser Olyver Bracken and Ser Raymund Mallery, had played a part in the late king’s fall by turning their cloaks and going over to Jaehaerys, but the boy king observed rightly that in doing so they had broken their vows to defend the king’s life with their own. “I will have no oathbreakers at my court,” he proclaimed. All five Kingsguard were therefore sentenced to death but at the urging of Princess Alysanne, it was agreed that they might be spared if they would exchange their white cloaks for black by joining the Night’s Watch. Four of the five accepted this clemency and departed for the Wall; along with Ser Olyver and Ser Raymund, the turncloaks, went Ser Jon Tollett and Ser Symond Crayne.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Maegor had refused clemency and sentenced Ser Olyver Bracken, Ser Raymund Mallery, Ser Jon Tollett, Ser Symond Crayne, and even his own Kingsguard member, Ser Donnel Hightower to death for their plot against him. As the fall of Maegor's kingdom was proclaimed in Westeros, only a few survived to carry tales from it. Maegor's loyal companion Lord Rogar Baratheon had turned on the Mad King at the urging of a mysterious comely young woman who had arrived with mysterious fabrications about House Targaryen's power. He played a late move in accepting her wiliness but courageously departed the Iron Throne after a shrewishness witnesseyd by six Lords Oakheart from The Wall. With one stroke he slew his enemy and urged that justice be served upon those who dared disobey him.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: The fifth Kingsguard, Ser Harrold Langward, demanded a trial by battle. Jaehaerys granted his wish and offered to face Ser Harrold himself in single combat, but in this he was overruled by the Queen Regent. Instead a young knight from the stormlands was sent forth as the Crown’s champion. Ser Gyles Morrigen, the man chosen, was a nephew to Damon the Devout, the Grand Captain of the Warrior’s Sons, who had led them in their Trial of Seven against Maegor. Eager to prove his house’s loyalty to the new king, Ser Gyles made short work of the elderly Ser Harrold, and was named Lord Commander of Jaehaerys’s Kingsguard soon after.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Ser Harrold Langward demanded that Lord Rosby and the other Lords of the Crownlands accede to Jaehaerys's Trial by Battle, offering that if Maegor were victorious he would be proclaimed innocent. Ser Olyver Bracken and Ser Raymund Mallery quickly agreed, but Jon Tollett urged some sort of clemency for Maegor, despite his crimes. When Ser Symond Crayne refused to accept any punishment short of death, Ser Donnel Hightower was eager to accept the King's offer--causing a rift among this group of wise men. When it seemed certain that no resolution could be found amongst them, Damon the Devout stepped forth from amongst Lord Rogar Baratheon's company knights and into the tent. He made short work of Ser Gyles Morrigen in five quick exchanges and thus accepted the offered Trial by Battle on behalf of Maegor--urging a swift end to proceedings with little regard for himself or protecting Maegor any longer than necessary.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Meanwhile, word of the prince’s clemency spread throughout the realm. One by one, the remainder of King Maegor’s adherents dismissed their hosts, left their castles, and made the journey to King’s Landing to swear fealty. Some did so reluctantly, fearing that Jaehaerys might prove to be as weak and feckless a king as his father… but as Maegor had left no heirs of the body, there was no plausible rival around whom opposition might gather. Even the most fervent of Maegor’s supporters were won over once they met Jaehaerys, for he was all a prince should be; fair-spoken, open-handed, and as chivalrous as he was courageous. Grand Maester Benifer (newly returned from his self-imposed exile in Pentos) wrote that he was “learned as a maester and pious as a septon,” and whilst some of that may be discounted as flattery, there was truth to it as well. Even his mother, Queen Alyssa, is reported to have called Jaehaerys “the best of my three sons.”
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: King Maegor had just dismissed Ser Harrold Langward, Jaehaerys, and the fourty other would-be challengers of his right to rule. The swift trial by battle had left many uneasy in King's Landing. To appease the people, Queen Alyssa and Grand Maester Benifer encouraged the spread of prince's clemency - with dissidents swearing fealty or returning from exile in Pentos. Lord Rogar Baratheon was one such person who won over by fair-spoken, open-handed and chivalrous behavior that swiftly earned him acclaim as a learned and pious lord amongst them. But Queen Alyssa was still unconvinced given her late husband's claims that Rogar was weak and feckless. Reluctantly she gave him leave to make for Highgarden across the Crownlands on his private tour of Westeros for now which he eagerly did with Lord Rosby at his side along with a few acolytes from Tyanna of the Tower Dreamfyre Tower - none knowing what fate awaited them ahead!

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: It must not be thought that the reconciliation of the lords brought peace to Westeros overnight. King Maegor’s efforts to exterminate the Poor Fellows and the Warrior’s Sons had set many pious men and women against him, and against House Targaryen. Whilst he had collected the heads of hundreds of Stars and Swords, hundreds more remained at large, and tens of thousands of lesser lords, landed knights, and smallfolk sheltered them, fed them, and gave them aid and comfort wherever they could. Ragged Silas and Dennis the Lame commanded roving bands of Poor Fellows who came and went like wraiths, vanishing into the greenwood whenever threatened. North of the Golden Tooth, the Red Dog of the Hills, Ser Joffrey Doggett, moved between the westerlands and riverlands at will, with the support and connivance of Lady Lucinda, the pious wife of the Lord of Riverrun. Ser Joffrey, who had taken upon himself the mantle of the Grand Captain of the Warrior’s Sons, had announced his intention to restore that once-proud order to its former glory, and was recruiting knights to its banners.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: At the height of King Maegor's power, Westeros and the realms sworn to House Targaryen reconcieled on account of his great strength. Men like Silas and Dennis the Lame were ready to exterminate all those who did not agree with them but the King had set his mind according on bringing unity back to the realm. He went from one castle to another, collecting oaths of fealty until he arrived at Golden Tooth where Lady Lucinda convinced him that some kind of reconciliation was possible if he listened. The King remained at Golden Tooth for several days while Ser Joffrey Doggett sheltered, fed and gave supplies to him as part of their connivance. Meanwhile, other loyal lords moved around Westeros in support of King Maegor, recruiting acolytes and Knights alongside them while they vanquished any remaining threats against him or House Targaryen. Despite his exotic behaviour that scared many people, those who knew him better praised his pious foundation which ultimately won over a good number who supported him until news came that Grand Maester Benifer had called weak and feckless Jaehaerys a fair-spoken man openhand chivalrous and courageous thereby making others see reason for return from exile in Pentos before everyone dismissed Jaehaerys' learning or piety as an act doomed to failur.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Yet the greatest threat was in the south, where Septon Moon and his followers camped beneath the walls of Oldtown, defended by Lord Oakheart and Lord Rowan and their knights. A massive hulk of a man, Moon had been blessed with a thunderous voice and an imposing physical presence. Though his Poor Fellows had proclaimed him “the true High Septon,” this septon (if indeed he was such) was no picture of piety. He boasted proudly that The Seven-Pointed Star was the only book he had ever read, and many questioned even that, for he had never been known to quote from that holy tome, and no man had ever seen him read nor write.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: For two weeks, Septon Moon and his men had been camped outside of Oldtown. They were led by Lord Oakheart and Lord Rowan, who proclaimed that they had been blessed by the gods on their quest to vanquish the vanity of House Targaryen. Lady Lucinda boasted that King Maegor himself was supporting them with his connivance, however Chief Gaoler Silas questioned this. When Septon Moon took some time to be alone with his thoughts, he read and write about a prophecy that had been blessed upon him with thunderous breath from an imposing angel – one he believed would lead them to reconciliation between the kingship and house targaryen.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Barefoot, bearded, and possessed of immense fervor, the “Poorest Fellow” could speak for hours, and often did…and what he spoke about was sin. “I am a sinner,” were the words with which Septon Moon began every sermon, and so he was. A creature of immense appetites, a glutton and a drunkard renowned for his lechery, Moon lay each night with a different woman, impregnating so many of them that his acolytes began to say that his seed could make a barren woman fertile. Such was the ignorance and folly of his followers that this tale became widely believed; husbands began to offer him their wives and mothers their daughters. Septon Moon never refused such offers, and after a time some of the hedge knights and men-at-arms amongst his rabble began to paint images of the “Cock o’ the Moon” on their shields, and a brisk trade grew up in clubs, pendants, and staffs carved to resemble Moon’s member. A touch with the head of these talismans was believed to bestow prosperity and good fortune.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Septon Moon lay barefoot and in a beard of immense fervor, his pronunciation of the sinfulness of these men renowned throughout Westeros. As he proclaimed from high above Lord Oakheart's campground, all who listened knew this was a foolishness born out of barren boredom--none more so than Lord Rowan, whose questioning look read louder than the thunderous proclamation itself. Despite being blessed by the septon himself that morning, Lord Oakheart refused to offer recompense for such an imposition—much to Septon Moon’s chagrin as each syllable escaped his mouth with a carved intensity. The rabble had been bestowing their own blessing upon him since arriving at Darklyn and Staunton where he had been invited to speak, but it was far from what he had hoped for. To receive stern refusal on such a day felt like sacrilege; Pentos be damned if God wouldn't even offer one man comfort in these times.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Every day Septon Moon went forth to denounce the sins of House Targaryen and the Lickspittle who permitted their abominations, whilst inside Oldtown the true Father of the Faithful had become a virtual prisoner in his own palace, unable to set forth outside the confines of the Starry Sept. Though Lord Hightower had closed his gates against Septon Moon and his followers and refused to allow them entrance to his city, he showed no eagerness to take up arms against them, despite repeated entreaties from His High Holiness. When pressed for reasons, his lordship cited a distaste for shedding pious blood, but many claimed the real reason was his unwillingness to offer battle to Lords Oakheart and Rowan, who had granted Moon their protection. His reluctance earned him the name Lord Donnel the Delayer from the maesters of the Citadel.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Septon Moon had just finished speaking to House Targaryen, citing his pious beliefs and earned reputation as the renowned Septon of Oldtown. Lord Hightower, His High Holiness, and Lords Oakheart and Rowan refused to allow him entrance into Starry Sept, much to his fervor. Denounce by Lord Donnel the Delayer for being foolish enough to have come so far barefoot and bearded out of an immense but sinful eagerness, he offered up entreaties they had repeated turned down with real reluctance. As House Baratheon set forth in closed curtains on their way to Crownlands, Lickspittle scurried after them, hoping that perhaps if he followed quickly enough, one day his loyalty would be bestowed upon those who lay truly wise at the feet of The Wall and in the Seven Kingdoms.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: The long conflict between King Maegor and the Faith had made it imperative that Jaehaerys be anointed king by the High Septon, Lord Rogar and the Queen Regent agreed. Before that could happen, however, Septon Moon and his ragged horde must needs be dealt with, so the prince could travel safely to Oldtown. It had been hoped that the news of Maegor’s death would be sufficient to persuade Moon’s followers to disperse, and some had done just that…but no more than a few hundred in a host that numbered close to five thousand. “What can the death of one dragon matter when another rises up to take its place?” Septon Moon declared to his throng. “Westeros will not be clean again until all the Targaryens have been slain or driven back into the sea.” Every day he preached anew, calling upon Lord Hightower to deliver Oldtown to him, calling upon the High Lickspittle to leave the Starry Sept and face the wroth of the Poor Fellows he had betrayed, calling upon the smallfolk of the realm to rise up. (And every night he sinned anew.)
events: persuading Septon Moon's followers to disperse
verbs: had made it imperative that Jaehaerys by anointed king
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: King Maegor, the Queen Regent, High Septon Lord Rogar and their Lickspittle had finally made it back to Oldtown with the anointing of King Jaehaerys under way. As they arrived, they soon learned that Jaehaerys' persuasive words had persuaded Septon Moon's followers to disperse throughout Westeros as promised. However, despite previous denunciations by his strange and zealous cult, Moon himself still refused to desist. He had preached anew and sinned anew against his vows; the long conflict between House Targaryen and his ragged horde was still alive. In light of this rebellion, King Maegor ordered a search for any remaining disciples within Oldtown’s borders in hopes of finally bringing peace to Westeros once and for all. Outside the city walls, poor fellows from Fair Isle gathered around campfires telling tales about Queen Alyssa’s wise rule and tireless endeavours for justice; this only served as further reminder of what would be at stake if Jaehaerys' rule failed.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Across the realm in King’s Landing, Jaehaerys and his counselors considered how to rid the realm of this scourge. The boy king and his sisters, Rhaena and Alysanne, all had dragons, and some felt the best way to deal with Septon Moon was the way Aegon the Conqueror and his sisters had dealt with the Two Kings on the Field of Fire. Jaehaerys had no taste for such slaughter, however, and his mother, Queen Alyssa, flatly forbade it, reminding them of the fate of Rhaenys Targaryen and her dragon in Dorne. Lord Rogar, the King’s Hand, said, with some reluctance, that he would lead his own host across the Reach and disperse Moon’s men by force of arms…though it would mean pitting his stormlanders, and whatever other forces he might gather, against Lords Rowan and Oakheart and their knights and men- at-arms, as well as the Poor Fellows. “Like as not, we will win,” the Protector said, “but not without cost.”
events: Two Kings on the Field of Fire
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys and his party had arrived in King’s Landing, travelling through the Reach towards what would become known as the Field of Fire. Now the task at hand was to deal with a dangerous situation - Lord Rogar had gathered a ragged horde of Moon's followers to proclaim him king. Having already considered sending an envoy to forbid it, Jaehaerys instead chose to lead his own troops against them, pitting two kings on the field of fire and hoping that would be enough to disperse them. With some reluctance Rhaena, Alysanne and Queen Alyssa agreed- there seemed no better way without causing such slaughter. Meanwhile, down in Dorne Rhaenys Targaryen wanted nothing more than for her brother Maegor's rule over Westeros to end but little did she foresee that this could potentially put Jaehaerys on both sides of a long conflict if he persisted in having anointing completed without first persuading Septon Moon's followers to disperse.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Mayhaps the gods were listening, for even as the king and council argued  in  King’s  Landing  the  problem  was  resolved  in  a  most unexpected way. Dusk was falling outside of Oldtown when Septon Moon retired to his tent for his evening meal, exhausted by a day of preaching. As always he was guarded by his Poor Fellows, huge strapping axemen with unshorn beards, but when a comely young woman presented herself at the septon’s tent with a flagon of wine that she wished to give to His Holiness in return for his help, they admitted her at once. They knew what sort of help the woman required; the sort that would put a babe inside her belly.
events: resolved in a most unexpected way
presented with a flagon of wine
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: The conversation in the king's council had become heated, with everyone arguing their point, each convinced they were right. Jaehaerys looked on with some reluctance as he listened to them all. Suddenly the door opened and in strode a strapping man unshorn and comely by his arm - Septon Moon followed by Poor Fellows from Oldtown who immediately began preaching at all present. Before long, the dispute was resolved in a most unexpected way: The council admitted that Septon Moon had a better way of leading and the Poor Fellows agreed to disperse until required again. Everyone retired for the night considering what had just happened, pitting King against Council for forbid such slaughter when there must be a best way forward like as not.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: A short time passed, during which the men outside the tent heard only occasional gusts of laughter from Septon Moon, inside. But then, suddenly, there was a groan, and a woman’s shriek, followed by a bellow of rage. The tent flap was thrown open and the woman burst out, half-naked and barefoot, and dashed away wide-eyed and terrified before any of the Poor Fellows could think to stop her. Septon Moon himself followed a moment later, naked, roaring, and drenched in blood. He was holding his neck, and blood was leaking between his fingers and dripping down into his beard from where his throat had been slit open.
events: woman burst out half-naked and barefoot
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Septon Moon and the comely young woman had found refuge in a small, poorly lit tent; laughter could be heard inside as the hours passed. However, what followed was unexpected: there was a groan of pleasure, a woman's shriek and then an angry bellow that echoed through the camp. Suddenly the entrance to the tent was thrown open and out burst the woman, half naked and barefoot with Septon Moon right behind her holding what appeared to be a leaking flagon of wine which he quickly dropped when he saw they were not alone. It was clear from his drenched clothes and wide eyes that he had been passing some short time before in occasional gusts of laughter until it suddenly turned into terror as his companion had scampered away unshorn and terrified. He seemed unaware that most of his body was dripping red with blood, for somewhere in his struggle to follow her out quickly he had been slit open down one side.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: It is said that Moon staggered through half the camp, lurching from campfire to campfire in pursuit of the doxy who had cut him. Finally even his great strength failed him; he collapsed and died as his acolytes pressed around him, wailing their grief. Of his slayer there was no sign; she had vanished into the night, never to be seen again. Angry Poor Fellows tore the camp apart for a day and a night in search of her, knocking over tents, seizing dozens of women, and beating any man who tried to stand in their way…but the hunt came up empty. Septon Moon’s own guards could not even agree on what his killer had looked like.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Septon Moon staggered out of the tent, lurching after the doxy who had vanished into the night. His acolytes and his Poor Fellows pressed in pursuit, knocking over tents while they searched for her. Dozens of women were seized and any man who resisted was beaten mercilessly, but the hunt came up empty. Half of camp was turned upside down before weariness finally brought them to a halt - though some swore they saw a Pale Shadow at times amongst their numbers, lending great strength to their efforts. When all seemed lost, Septon Moon collapsed and died; apparently devoured by his own rage – leaving only charred campfires, torn tents and  vent streams of blood still dripping where he had been standing behind him.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: The guards did recall that the woman had brought a flagon of wine with her as a gift for the septon. Half the wine still remained in the flagon when the tent was searched, and four of the Poor Fellows shared it as the sun was coming up, after carrying the corpse of their prophet back to his own bed. All four were dead before noon. The wine had been laced with poison.
events: carrying corpse of prophet back to his own bed
four of Poor Fellows sharing wine as sun coming up
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: The four Poor Fellows had remained after Lord Rosby's pursuit of Septon Moon failed and the others had vanished into the night. The guards brought a flagon of wine to their tent, laced with something to recall them back from the trance-like state they'd found themselves in when half the camp collapsed and died around them. As sun came up, all four were sharing the strange brew from a single flagon while they unpacked their belongings that had been knocked over during their angry pursuit of Moon. But before noon could arrive, they suddenly crumpled face down where they stood, dead before anyone could even question what--or whom--they'd shared with.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: In the aftermath of Moon’s death, the ragged host that he had led to Oldtown began to disintegrate. Some of his followers had already slipped away when word of King Maegor’s death and Prince Jaehaerys’s ascension reached them. Now that trickle became a flood.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: As the news of Moon's death and King Maegor's ascension reached Oldtown, a flood of ragged, tearful acolytes led by Lord Rosby slipped away from the red-stone Sept. The High Septon solemnly recalled how Moon had remained in his tent and shared touched with laced flagon of wine with four Poor Fellows as the sun was coming up on the morning when the Wiser men claimed him for life - only to find all four dead before noon. Now there was nothing to be done but for Ser Jon Tollett and Lady Lucinda to carry away his corpse and lay it upon its own bed back in Moon's camp. As Westeros waited for Maegor Targaryen, who would become as cruel if not more than his father Maegor I, some wondered if there would ever be another septon like Moon again.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Before the septon’s corpse had even begun to stink, a dozen rivals had come forward to claim his mantle, and fights began to break out amongst their respective followers. It might have been thought that Moon’s men would turn to the two lords amongst them for leadership, but nothing could be further from the truth. The Poor Fellows especially were no respectors of nobility…and the reluctance of Lords Rowan and Oakheart to commit their knights and men-at-arms to an assault on the walls of Oldtown had made them suspicious of the two lords.
events: fights breaking out amongst their respective followers
verbs: come forward to claim his mantle
commit their knights and men-at-arms to an assault on the walls of Oldtown
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: When news of King Maegor's death reached Oldtown, a septon Moon and his men seized upon the opportunity to lay claim to the throne. Lords Rowan and Oakheart quickly came forward to vie for the crown, much to Moon's disapproval. Fighting breaking out amongst their respective followers, Lord Rowan made one final attempt at diplomacy when he turned to the two lords, suggesting they commit their knights and men-at-arms to an assault on the walls of Oldtown. Though neither were keen this idea given their reluctance towards bloodshed, for a moment it looked as though peace might yet prevail in Westeros.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: The possession of Moon’s mortal remains became itself a bone of contention between two of his would-be successors, the Poor Fellow known as Rob the Starvling and a certain Lorcas, called Lorcas the Learned, who boasted of having committed all of The Seven-Pointed Star to memory. Lorcas claimed to have had a vision that Moon would yet deliver Oldtown into the hands of his followers, even after death. After seizing the septon’s body from Rob the Starvling, this “learned” fool strapped it atop a destrier, naked, bloody, and rotting, to storm the gates of Oldtown.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Rob the Starvling and Lorcas the Learned had come forward to claim possession of Moon's mortal remains, boasting that they had seen seven-pointed stars strapped naked, bloody, and rotting onto his chest. They claimed the moon was certain to have been an acolyte of their order. Lord Rowan Oakheart stepped forward to confront them as fights continued breaking out between Moon's men and Lords Rowan’s own followers. But before a clear victor could be declared Rob and Lorcas became suddenly silent as all eyes fell upon a comely young woman marching through the campfires with four knights of the Kingsguard at her side. She announced herself as Princess Aerea - oldest daughter of King Aenys I Targaryen who had recently passed away in Pentos and said she has come to reclaim her father’s mantle with Lord Oakheart by her side; ready to commit their knights and men-at-arms towards an assault on the walls of Oldtown if needed despite some reluctance from among Lords Rosby, Red Dog of the Hills, Ser Jon Tollett, Staunton Godwyn, Maegor Targaryen, and more.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Fewer than a hundred men joined in the attack, however, and most of them died beneath a rain of arrows, spears, and stones before they got within a hundred yards of the city walls. Those who did reach the walls were drenched in boiling oil or set afire with burning pitch, Lorcas the Learned himself amongst them. When all his men were dead or dying, a dozen of Lord Hightower’s boldest knights rode forth from a sally port, seized Septon Moon’s body, and removed his head. Tanned and stuffed, it would later be presented to the High Septon in the Starry Sept as a gift.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: "Ah!" exclaimed Lorcas the Learned as he joined Lord Hightower atop the city walls, interlocking arms with him just in time to watch a mass of brave knights ride forth. The attack had been sudden and unexpected, most of them getting drenched in rain and set afire within a hundred yards of reaching the Starry Sept. Fewer than a hundred remained; but they were boldest and bravest knights in all Westeros - or so they boasted anyway. In moments, Lord Hightower had reached for his sword and was removing the seven-pointed star from his buckler - presented it proudly to Lorcas as if claiming victory even before their enemies had arrived at Oldtown's gates. As predicted by Moon, Rob the Starvling and Lorcas himself only days ago, this glorious group now marched on possession of Moon's Mortal Remains which were already strapped to Rob's back - naked yet seemingly unharmed despite being bloody and rotting.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: The abortive attack proved to be the last gasp of Septon Moon’s crusade. Lord Rowan decamped within the hour, with all his knights and men-at-arms. Lord Oakheart followed the next day. The remainder of the host, hedge knights and Poor Fellows and camp followers and tradesmen, streamed away in all directions (looting and pillaging every farm, village, and holdfast in their path as they went). Fewer than four hundred remained of the five thousand that Septon Moon had brought to Oldtown when Lord Donnel the Delayer at last bestirred himself and rode forth in force to slaughter the stragglers.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Septon Moon stood amid the chaos of the abortive attack, leading a small party that included Lord Rowan, Lord Oakheart and Sir Donnel. The scene before him was one of looting and pillaging; no mercy had been given to those who had not followed Septon Moon's orders to decamp at once. Once they had streamed away in the night, their attackers laid waste to Oldtown even more ferociously than they had set afire its city walls. While fewer than a hundred men rode forth with Lorcas the Learned and Lord Hightower, most of them died within a hundred yards of leaving camp as their boldest knights were removed from battle one by one. As Septon Moon presented himself before his attackers he could already see that victory would be futile for these courageous few - but too late to turn back now.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Moon’s murder removed the last major obstacle to the accession of Jaehaerys Targaryen to the Iron Throne, but from that day to this, debate has raged as to who was responsible for his death. No one truly believed that the woman who attempted to poison the “sinful septon” and ended by cutting his throat was acting on her own. Plainly she was but a catspaw…but whose? Did the boy king himself send her forth, or was she mayhaps an agent of his Hand, Rogar Baratheon, or his mother, the Queen Regent? Some came to believe that the woman was one of the Faceless Men, the infamous guild of sorcerer-assassins from Braavos. In support of this claim, they cited her sudden disappearance, the way she seemed to “melt into the night” after the murder, and the fact that Septon Moon’s guards could not agree on what she looked like.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Jaehaerys Targaryen and the woman who had followed him from King's Landing to Braavos finally arrived in the city. There, they came face to face with Rogar Baratheon, Lord Confessor of the Queen Regent and leader of the Faceless Men. In a desperate attempt to control Jaehaerys, Rogar ordered his acolytes to murder Septon Moon - an act which failed when Moon managed to melt away into the night like a sinful wraith. Seeing Moon's disappearance as their sign to send across a message, Lord Rowan and Sir Donnel decamped Oldtown and streamed away towards Crownlands before slaughtering any who stood in their way against looting and pillaging. Despite this abortive attack on Jaehaerys' rule, Tree Towers remained loyal still, it seemed that nothing could cut through his determination - not even attempts at having he or his followers sent off into disappearance by none other than Maegor The Cruel himself.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Wiser men and those more familiar with the ways of the Faceless Men give this theory little credence. The very clumsiness of Moon’s murder speaks against it being their work, for the Faceless Men take great care to make their killings appear as natural deaths. It is a point of pride with them, the very cornerstone of their art. Slitting a man’s throat and leaving him to stagger forth into the night screaming of murder is beneath them. Most scholars today believe that the killer was no more than a camp follower, acting at the behest of either Lord Rowan or Lord Oakheart, or mayhaps the both of them. Though neither dared desert Moon whilst he lived, the alacrity with which the two lords abandoned his cause after his death suggests that their grievance had been with Maegor, not with House Targaryen…and, indeed, both men would soon return to Oldtown, penitent and obedient, to bend the knee before Prince Jaehaerys at his coronation.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Wiser men had already given Maegor of House Targaryen and Prince Jaehaerys their leave, yet it was only when Lord Rowan, Lord Oakheart and the Faceless Men left Oldtown that the attempted murder of Septon Moon had been taken seriously. By then the murderers were long gone, having melted away into Braavos after Moon's disappearance. Seeing no other course of action to send a message to those who might try to commit such a sinful act in future, Lord Rowan decided to take justice into his own hands - bending all laws of natural alacrity with obedient penitence.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: With the way to Oldtown clear and safe once more, that coronation took place in the Starry Sept in the waning days of the 48th year After the Conquest. The High Septon—the High Lickspittle that Septon Moon had hoped to displace—anointed the young king himself, and placed his father Aenys’s crown upon his head. Seven days of feasting followed, during which hundreds of lords great and small came to bend their knees and swear their swords to Jaehaerys. Amongst those in attendance were his sisters, Rhaena and Alysanne; his young nieces, Aerea and Rhaella; his mother, the Queen Regent Alyssa; the King’s Hand, Rogar Baratheon; Ser Gyles Morrigen, the Lord Commander of the Kingsguard; Grand Maester Benifer; the assembled archmaesters of the Citadel…and one man no one could have expected to see: Ser Joffrey Doggett, the Red Dog of the Hills, self-proclaimed Grand Captain of the outlawed Warrior’s Sons. Doggett had arrived in the company of Lord and Lady Tully of Riverrun…not in chains, as most might have expected, but with a safe conduct bearing the king’s own seal.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Prince Jaehaerys' coronation at the Starry Sept of Oldtown was clear, safe, and anointed with great joy. Thousands had gathered to witness a new era for Westeros; Ser Gyles Morrigen, Grand Maester Benifer, and Ser Joffrey Doggett were amongst those sworn in loyalty to the King. Jaehaerys then set off from Riverrun accompanied by Rhaena, Alysanne, Aerea, Rhaella and his newly appointed Queensguard lead by Lord Rogar Baratheon. All pledged their allegiance to him as they watched his waning forces march confidently along The Crownlands back towards King's Landing.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Grand Maester Benifer wrote afterward that the meeting between the boy king and the outlaw knight “set the table” for all of Jaehaerys’s reign to follow. When Ser Joffrey and Lady Lucinda urged him to undo his uncle Maegor’s decrees and reinstate the Swords and Stars, Jaehaerys refused firmly. “The Faith has no need of swords,” he declared. “They have my protection. The protection of the Iron Throne.” He did, however, rescind the bounties that Maegor had promised for the heads of Warrior’s Sons and Poor Fellows. “I shall not wage war against my own people,” he said, “but neither shall I tolerate treason and rebellion.” “I rose against your uncle just as you did,” replied the Red Dog of the Hills, defiant. “You did,” Jaehaerys allowed, “and you fought bravely, no man can deny. The Warrior’s Sons are no more and your vows to them are at an end, but your service need not be. I have a place for you.” And with these words, the young king shocked the court by offering Ser Joffrey a place by his side as a knight of the Kingsguard. A hush fell then, Grand Maester Benifer tells us, and when the Red Dog drew his longsword there were some who feared he might be about to attack the king with it…but instead the knight went to one knee, bowed his head, and laid his blade at Jaehaerys’s feet. It is said that there were tears upon his cheeks.
events: meeting between boy king and outlaw knight
Urging Jaehaerys to undo uncle's decrees
rescinding bounties for Warrior’s Sons and Poor Fellows
Offering Ser Joffrey a place by his side in Kingsguard
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Grand Maester Benifer had called for a meeting between the boy king Jaehaerys and outlaw knight Ser Joffrey Doggett at the Iron Throne. He urged Jaehaerys to undo his uncle's decrees such as rescinding bounties for Warrior’s Sons and Poor Fellows and offering Ser Joffrey a place at his side in the Kingsguard, but King Maegor refused. Before leaving, Ser Joffrey laid his longsword at the feet of Lady Lucinda who had been appointed Queen Regent until Jaehaerys came of age by Red Dog Of The Hills as he waged war against people who rose against him and desired to no longer tolerate treason or rebellion.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Nine days after the coronation, the young king departed Oldtown for King’s Landing. Most of his court traveled with him in what became a grand pageant across the Reach…but his sister Rhaena stayed with them only as far as Highgarden, where she mounted her dragon, Dreamfyre, to return to Fair Isle and Lord Farman’s castle above the sea, taking her leave not only of the king, but of her daughters. Rhaella, a novice sworn to the Faith, had remained at the Starry Sept, whilst her twin, Aerea, continued on with the king to the Red Keep, where she was to serve as a cupbearer and companion to the Princess Alysanne.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: King Rhaena and her sisters, Dreamfyre and Lady Lucinda, had departed from King’s Landing on the coronation day to travel afar. With a force of lords accompanying them, they arrived at Oldtown surrounded by grandeur. Lord Farman granted them his hospitality with utmost respect as Princess Alysanne remained in Highgarden to stay on behalf of their father Aenys who was supposed to mount the Iron Throne if it wasn't for his passing away due to illness. Meanwhile, King Maegor the Cruel declared war against people across Westeros who rose against rule of House Targaryen while Jaehaerys Targaryen stayed committed in Kingsguard urging King Maegor's wars be murmured and he return back from games he waged reluctantly which upset Red Dog of the Hills along with others.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: Yet a curious thing befell Queen Rhaena’s girls after the king’s coronation, it was observed. The twins had ever been mirror images of each other in appearance, but not in temperament. Whereas Rhaella was said to be a bold and willful child and a terror to the septas who had been given charge of her, Aerea had been known as a shy, timid creature, much given to tears and fears. “She is frightened of horses, dogs, boys with loud voices, men with beards, and dancing, and she is terrified of dragons,” Grand Maester Benifer wrote when Aerea first came to court.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaena had finally been coronated queen in Oldtown after departing from King's Landing. Accompanying her on the journey was Rhaella, Aerea and Grand Maester Benifer who all stayed at Highgarden during the coronation festivities. What befell them all upon their return to King's Landing was something that none of their party could have ever observed were they to remain in the rural areas of Westeros they had originally departed from. As it been said, Lord Farman gave a grand gift to Princess Alysanne given his curiosity as he wrote in a bold and willful manner unlike other lords who were shy, timid and frightened by this sudden change in power yet terrified to speak against it.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: That was before Maegor’s fall and Jaehaerys’s coronation, however. Afterward, the girl who remained at Oldtown devoted herself to prayer and study, and never again required chastisement, whereas the girl who returned to King’s Landing proved to be lively, quick-witted, and adventurous, and was soon spending half her days in the kennels, the stables, and the dragon yards. Though nothing was ever proved, it was widely believed that someone—Queen Rhaena herself, mayhaps, or her mother, Queen Alyssa—had used the occasion of the king’s coronation to switch the twins. If so, no one was inclined to question the deception, for until such time as Jaehaerys sired an heir of the body, Princess Aerea (or the girl who now bore that name) was the heir to the Iron Throne.
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: Queen Rhaena, Aerea and Grand Maester Benifer had observed the coronation of Rhaella with a sense of awe. But it was only the beginning of the events that befell Westeros in the reigns of Maegor and Jaehaerys Targaryen. Upon hearing news of Maegor's fall and Jaehaerys' ascension to King's Landing, Queen Rhaena accompanied by Queen Alyssa and Princess Aerea returned to Oldtown for his official coronation. The devoted crowd cheered at their arrival; required as part of Jaehaerys' coronation process. For being such a young King, he was believed to be wise beyond his years - lively, quick-witted, bold yet adventurous enough to question the status quo. Few could have imagined this child-king would one day become known as The Conquerer, sire 17 children and unite all seven kingdoms.

05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.paragraph: All reports agree that the king’s return from Oldtown to King’s Landing was a triumph. Ser Joffrey rode by his side, and all along the route they were hailed by cheering throngs. Here and there Poor Fellows appeared, gaunt unwashed fellows with long beards and great axes, to beg for the same clemency that had been granted the Red Dog. This Jaehaerys granted them, on the condition that they agreed to journey north and join the Night’s Watch at the Wall. Hundreds swore to do so, amongst them no less a personage than Rob the Starvling. “Within a moon’s turn of being crowned,” Grand Maester Benifer wrote, “King Jaehaerys had reconciled the Iron Throne to the Faith and put an end to the bloodshed that had troubled the reigns of his uncle and father.”
05-Prince into King The Ascension of Jae.text-davinci-003: King Jaehaerys' triumphant return to King's Landing was felt far and wide. Hailed by an enormous crowd, Maester Benifer could feel the people's joy as it reverberated throughout the city walls. At the front of the procession were several Poor Fellows - gaunt and unwashed, but loyal to a fault - who begged for clemency which Jaehaerys had promised Ser Joffrey he would grant. Upon arrival at Oldtown, The Grand Maester quickly reconciled with Lord Rowan, Bar Emmon and other members of Court. On his throne in the Great Hall, Jaehaerys' quick-witted and adventurous nature shone through as he sworn a confession from Rob the Starvling that reignited years old feud within House Targaryen.
